call_title: Property Rights in the Age of Programmable Money | Alexander Chepurnoy

topics.title: Introduction to Programmable Money Property Rights
topics.summary: Alexander Chepurnoy introduces the topic connecting US-sanctioned smart contracts, programmable money, tokenized assets, and property rights. The presentation will explore how property rights evolve in the context of blockchain and autonomous code.

topics.title: Tornado Cash Case and Autonomous Contract Ownership
topics.summary: Discussion of the Tornado Cash privacy protocol case where a U.S. federal appeals court ruled that immutable smart contracts cannot be considered property of any entity. This establishes legal precedent for autonomous code ownership in blockchain systems.

topics.title: Programmable Money Concepts and Protection Mechanisms
topics.summary: Explanation of how programmable money differs from physical money, with digital banknotes protecting themselves through public keys and programmable logic. Covers blockchain-based systems like Ergo and Bitcoin, as well as potential CBDC implementations.

topics.title: Types of Digital Asset Ownership Models
topics.summary: Classification of ownership types in programmable money: individual ownership (single key), cooperative property (multiple keys with quorum), and contractual property (autonomous contracts with no defined owner). Contractual ownership includes cases where owners are determined by randomness or blockchain state.

topics.title: Tokenized Art and Ownership Quantization
topics.summary: Overview of art tokenization approaches including dividing physical art ownership into multiple tokens and creating digital art NFTs. Introduces the concept of quantization dimension where ownership can be represented by single or multiple tokens.

topics.title: Complex Art Ownership Scenarios and Examples
topics.summary: Detailed example of a 1000-token art object with mixed ownership: 200 tokens owned by gallery, 100 by painter cooperative with multisig, and 700 tokens controlled by auction contract. Demonstrates how different ownership models can coexist for single assets.

topics.title: Advanced Financial Models for Art Trading
topics.summary: Exploration of new financial models for art sales including liquidity provision, time locks, and automated market makers. Discusses how contractual ownership enables experimental sales models and financialization of art becomes an art form itself.

topics.title: Ergo Ecosystem Tools for Art and Finance
topics.summary: Overview of available Ergo tools including airdrop tools, Auction Coin framework, MewFinance for fundraising, Paideia for DAOs, NFT auctions, and decentralized exchanges. Encourages experimentation with sustainable finance models for artists and concludes with resource links.
